awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Performance Incentives for Organ Transplantation Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will impact the Nation's healthcare system by ensuring more effective use of donor transplant organs.  Organ transplantation is the most effective, and often the only viable, therapy for end-stage organ failure. Unfortunately, the demand for organs greatly exceeds the supply. To ensure that transplant centers are effectively using these scarce organs, this award will develop new transplant center evaluation criteria to incentivize transplant centers to improve their post-transplant outcomes and maximize transplantation volume. This award will lead to a deeper understanding of current pay-for-performance initiatives in the transplantation system and in other healthcare settings by examining the interplay between societal goals and provider incentives. The goals of this award are in line with the NSF mission goal of promoting the advancement of the national health. This award will fund a doctoral student in inter-disciplinary research and create educational materials for both operations researchers and transplantation professionals at the Texas Medical Center. This award will involve students from underrepresented groups and engage in outreach efforts through various programs at Rice University and the University of Houston.

This research will build a bilevel optimization framework to model the interaction between the societal perspective and the goals of individual transplant centers to determine incentives that simultaneously maximize societal and center-level benefits. This framework (1) formulates the societal perspective (the leader) that quantifies the utility-adjusted, national benefit and determines societally optimal incentive parameters, and (2) models each transplant center's perspective (the followers) as a sequential, stochastic decision-making problem so as to maximize its transplant volume subject to the societal incentives. Bilevel models are considered among the hardest optimization models. This research will lead to advances in bilevel optimization where the followers' problems are sequential and stochastic. To address the computational challenges, the researchers will develop approximation techniques leveraging the fluid model structure of each center's problem and chance-constrained programming techniques, and build efficient algorithms based on decomposition, branch-and-cut methods, and high-performance computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organ transplantation is an increasingly common therapy for end-stage organ failure. To ensure the efficient utilization of scarce donor organs, federal health agencies routinely evaluate transplant programs based on their patients' post-transplantation survival outcomes relative to national averages. However, clinical observations indicated that the regulations may have had the opposite effect, causing transplant programs to become risk-averse and leading to a decline in transplant volume. This project sought to analyze the role of outcome-based regulations in inducing this program behavior, and to propose alternative measures that may address their unintended consequences.

We first sought to characterize the rational response of a transplant program to outcome-based regulations. We considered a transplant program that seeks to select patients from an incoming stream of transplant candidates to maximize its transplant volume while controlling the risk of penalization. We formulated the problem as a chance-constrained mixed-integer program (MIP). Through analytical results and numerical experiments calibrated with real transplant data, we demonstrated that risk-averse patient selection is often indeed a rational strategy. That is, it may be optimal for a transplant program to curtail its transplant volume to avoid penalization. 

One of the intended objectives of outcome-based regulations was to incentivize transplant programs to improve their post-transplantation outcomes. To analyze the effectiveness of the regulations in achieving this objective, we developed a bilevel, game-theoretic model: each lower-level player (transplant program) seeks to maximize its utility as a function of transplant volume, cost of improving outcomes, and penalty associated with getting flagged, while the upper-level player is a federal agency who announces reimbursement/penalty policy. By analyzing equilibria of this game, we demonstrated that under the existing regulations, transplant programs may be incentivized to reject patients instead of investing resources to improve outcomes. To eliminate these mis-incentives, we proposed an alternative pay-for-performance scheme that ties outcomes directly to federal reimbursement. We demonstrated that this scheme could incentivize programs to improve outcomes without inducing adverse patient selection.

This research led to methodological advances in approximation of chance-constrained, large-scale MIPs. We proved the existence of a steady-state patient admission policy over time, which we exploited to develop an efficient, interpretable solution algorithm. This solution approach can be generalized to other settings that involve an MIP with chance constraints that are imposed sequentially in a rolling horizon manner. This research has also contributed to the construction of integer programming value functions, which helps develop solution methods for bilevel optimization problems with multiple chance-constrained MIP follower problems. We also developed a novel inverse optimization model that uses past medical decisions to infer attributes that are representative of the decision-makers' preferences. This model is useful for quantifying the misalignment between the policymakers and transplantation centers. This project provided interdisciplinary training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Houston. PI Lee hosted various K-12 STEM education workshops at local elementary and high schools in the greater Houston area, where this research was used for promoting STEM research.

Our findings will aid the development of future regulations that improve nationwide post-transplantation outcomes without limiting transplant access. More broadly, this research provides insight into pay-for-performance initiatives in the transplantation system and in other healthcare settings by examining the interplay between societal goals and provider incentives.
